turn.0: ELI5: In Chemistry, why are they called the Noble Gases? I know they "don't share", but is that a crack at aristocrats or more of a Buddhist-style respectful reference to the nobility?
turn.1: Well we needed to start between the difference between materials and phases, so a couple steps back still
turn.2: I know materials vs. phases I just didn't understand the difference between a solid noble gas and a solid metal
turn.3: Right, because of the difference between a material (metal) and a phase (solid)
turn.4: Can I have a link or a summary or a list of what you mean exactly by materials?
turn.5: Im referring to different types of atoms/molecules, the periodic table is a list of base atoms and you can use NIST for list of molecules but thats absurdly long.
turn.6: What are 4 other types of materials besides metal? Or even 2?
turn.7: Each atom and each molecule is a type of material, there are billions. There can be large groupings (by things like phases at room temperature) but every different molecule is different.
turn.8: Okay, if metals are one large grouping, what is one other large grouping? Can you name a single one?
turn.9: Metals is a large grouping that consists of alkali metals, transition metals, rare earth metals, alkali earth metals and the f-block at the bottom.  On the right there are the noble gases, the halides the carbon like atoms and I forget the last one. They also go by their column numbers.  And thats just pure materials not counting compounds/molecules. There are millions involving carbon alone.
